review.title: Synergistic Team Composition
review.abstract: Effective teams are crucial for organisations, especially in environments that require teams to be constantly created and dismantled, such as software development, scientific experiments, crowd-sourcing, or the classroom. Key factors influencing team performance are competences and personality of team members. Hence, we present a computational model to compose proficient and congenial teams based on individuals' personalities and their competences to perform tasks of different nature. With this purpose, we extend Wilde's post-Jungian method for team composition, which solely employs individuals' personalities. The aim of this study is to create a model to partition agents into teams that are balanced in competences, personality and gender. Finally, we present some preliminary empirical results that we obtained when analysing student performance. Results show the benefits of a more informed team composition that exploits individuals' competences besides information about their personalities.

metadata.title: Synergistic Team Composition

sections.text: To this end, we are extending Wild's post-Jungian method of team composition, in which only individuals "personalities are used. The aim of this study is to develop a model for dividing agents into teams that are balanced in skills, personality and gender. Finally, we present some preliminary empirical results we have achieved in analyzing student performance. Results show the benefits of a more informed team composition that exploits individuals" competences alongside information about their personalities. sections.heading: 3. PERSONALITY
sections.text: In this section, we will discuss the most prominent approaches to measuring human personality and explain the details of the method we have chosen to investigate. Personality determines people's behavior, cognition and emotion. Different personality theorists present their own definitions of personality and various ways to measure them based on their theoretical positions.The most popular approach is to determine personality through a series of questions. There are several simplified rules that have been developed over the years to profile human personality.The most popular are: 1. the five-factor model (aka FFM or "Big Five"), which uses five broad dimensions to describe human personality [13]; 2. belbin theory [6], which provides a theory of how different role types affect teamwork; and 3. the Myers-Briggs type indicator (MBTI) scheme designed to show psychological preferences in how people perceive the world and make decisions.

sections.heading: 4. TEAM COMPOSITION MODEL
sections.text: In this section, we present and formalize our problem of team composition. First, in Section 4.1, we introduce the basic terms of agent, personality, competence, and team, on the basis of which we formalize our problem. Then, we formalize the concept of assigning tasks to an individual team and task, and characterize different types of tasks. Section 4.3 and 4.4 show how to evaluate the competence and degree of togetherness of a team. Based on these measures, in Section 4.6, we formalize the synergistic problem of team composition.

sections.heading: 4.1 Basic definitions
sections.text: In our model, we consider each agent to be human. We characterize each agent by the following characteristics: • A unique identification that distinguishes an agent from others (e.g. ID number, passport number, employee ID or student ID). • Gender. Human agents are either a man or a woman. • A personality represented by four personality traits. • Each personality trait is a number between -1 and 1. • A competence integrates knowledge, skills, personal values and attitudes that enable an agent to act correctly in a job, task or situation. [33] Each agent is assumed to possess a set of competences with associated levels of competence. This phrase may vary over time as an agent. Next, we formalize the concepts presented above. Definition 1. A personality profile is a vector < sn, tf, ei, ei, pj >.

sections.heading: 4.4 Evaluating team congeniality
sections.text: Inspired by the experiments of Douglass J. Wilde [37], we define the team usefulness function for congeniality ucon (K) so that: • it evaluates more teams whose SN and TF personality dimensions are as diverse as possible; • it prefers teams with at least one agent with positive EI and TF dimensions and negative PJ dimensions, namely an extroverted, thinking and judging agent (referred to as ETJ personality); • it evaluates more teams with at least one introverted agent; • it evaluates the gender balance in a team. Therefore, the higher the value of the function ucon (K), the more diverse the team is. Formally, this team usefulness function is defined as follows: ucon (K) = σTF (K) + maxai-K (K) + maxai-K (0, α) · pi-pi, 0), ai-K (max.

sections.heading: 4.5 Evaluating synergistic teams
sections.text: Depending on the task type, a different meaning for congeniality and competence should be given. Thus, creative tasks require a high degree of communication and exchange of ideas, and therefore teams require a certain degree of congeniality. Repeated tasks require good competence and less communication. The meaning of competence (λ) and congeniality (µ) is therefore a fundamental aspect of the task type. Now, in a team, we can combine its competence value (in Eq. 1) with its congeniality value (in Eq. 2) to measure its synergistic value. Definition 11. sections.heading: 4.6 The synergistic team composition problem
sections.text: What follows is that there are several instances of the same task that we have to perform. In view of a number of Agent A, our goal is to divide them into teams so that each team and the overall division of agents into teams is balanced in terms of skills, personality and gender. We will refer to these balanced teams as synergistic teams, which means that they are both likeable and competent. Therefore, we can consider our team composition problem as a certain type of fixed composition problem. We will refer to any composition of A as team composition. However, we are interested in a certain type of team composition, namely those where the teams are defined by size m as follow.Definition 12. sections.heading: 5. SOLVING STFP
sections.text: In this section, we describe an algorithm, the so-called SynTeam, which solves the synergistic team building problem described above. We begin by describing the division of the agents into a partition (see subsection 5.1). Next, we move on to the problem of assigning competencies in a task to team members (see subsection 5.2), so that the benefits of the synergistic function are maximized. Finally, we explain to SynTeam that it is a greedy algorithm that quickly finds a first, local solution in order to subsequently improve it, in the hope of achieving a global optimum. 5.1 How do we divide agents? We note down the number of agents in A using n = | A, using m ² N the target number of agents in each team, and using b the minimum total number of agents, b = bn / mc. We define the quantity distribution of agents in teams (m m m m), note down T: N · N · ² N, N = n, > ² (n = (b), >: n (m m m m m), >, n = m m m m m, m m m m m, m m m m m, m m m m, m, >, n = 1, n, n = n, m, m, m m m m m m, m m m, m m =, m m m m m m m, m m, m, m, n ², > 2, n ², n: n = n (b).

sections.heading: 5.2 Solving an Assignment
sections.text: There are various methods to assign to all such assignments, and we have decided to solve our assignment problem by using the minimum cost flow model (1), which is one of the most basic problems within network flow theory and can be efficiently solved. (1) It has been proven that the minimum cost flow problem in O (m · log (n) · 3 (m + n · log (n))) time with n nodes and m arcs.Our problem is as follows: There are a number of agents in Team K and a number of competence requests in task. Each agent can be assigned to a competence that varies according to the level of competence of the assigned competence. We want each competence to be assigned to at least one agent and each agent that has assigned at least one competence in a way that the total cost (which is both undercompetent and overcompetent) of the assignment is minimal.

sections.heading: 6. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6.1 Experimental Setting
sections.text: The "Institut Torras i Bages" is a state school near Barcelona. There, in the last 5 years, in its final thesis ("Treball de S'ıntesi"), a collaboration has been implemented with a constant and significant increase in the scores and quality of the final product that the students are supposed to deliver. This task lasts one week and is designed to verify whether and to what extent the students have achieved the goals set out in the various curricula. It is a work that promotes teamwork, research and testing of relations with the environment. Students work in teams and present their work at the end of each activity to a group of teachers who assess the content, presentation and collaboration between the team members. It is a creative task, but one that requires a high level of competence.

sections.heading: 6.2 Data Collection
sections.text: In current school practice, students are following their own manual method based on knowledge of the students, their competencies, background and social situation. (This year, we used our grouping system only on the basis of personality (Synbesti), which allowed us to divide them into teams of size three for each class. Tutors rated each team in each partition, giving an integral value v (1, 10). (Use of computers and / or mobile phones means their expectation of the performance of each team. Each student team was asked to assign the group of interdisciplinary ac algorithms 1: TeamRequire: A The list of agents Require: T (| A, m). Quantitative team distribution: Pbest.

sections.heading: 6.3 Results
sections.text: Given Kendall's multiple team composition methods, we are interested in comparing them to know which method better predicts team performance. Therefore, we generate multiple team rankings based on the scores obtained through different methods. Firstly, we generate a ranking based on actual team performance, which will be our basis for comparing other rankings. Secondly, we create a ranking based on expert ratings. Finally, we generate multiple rankings based on calculated synergistic scores with varying degrees of ingenuity and competence. Since "Traball de S'ıntesi" is a creative task, we want to examine the rating function based on the parameters µ > 0 and λ = 1 − µ. Specifically, we want to observe how rankings change when the importance of competences is increased. Note that teachers and actual performance rankings can involve ties, as the pool of possible grades is more discreet (which is highly unlikely in the case of SynTeam rankings).

sections.heading: 7. DISCUSSION
sections.text: In this work, we have introduced SynTeam, an algorithm for dividing groups of people into competent, gender-specific and psychologically balanced teams. To our knowledge, SynTeam is the first computational model to form synergistic teams that not only work well together, but are competent enough to perform a task that requires particular expertise. We have decided to evaluate our algorithm in the context of a classroom. In addition to obvious advantages of personal observation of students, this scenario has given us the opportunity to compare our results with real practice currently in use. Results show that SynTeam is able to predict team performance better than the experts who know the students, their social background, their skills and cognitive abilities. The algorithm is potentially useful for any organization that faces the need to optimize its problem-solving teams (e.g. a classroom, a company, a research unit). The algorithm assembles teams purely automatically, without consulting experts, which is a huge advantage to them.

metadata.abstractText: Effective teams are crucial for organisations, especially in environments that require teams to be constantly created and dismantled, such as software development, scientific experiments, crowd-sourcing, or the classroom. Key factors influencing team performance are competences and personality of team members. Hence, we present a computational model to compose proficient and congenial teams based on individuals’ personalities and their competences to perform tasks of different nature. With this purpose, we extend Wilde’s post-Jungian method for team composition, which solely employs individuals’ personalities. The aim of this study is to create a model to partition agents into teams that are balanced in competences, personality and gender. Finally, we present some preliminary empirical results that we obtained when analysing student performance. Results show the benefits of a more informed team composition that exploits individuals’ competences besides information about their personalities.
